turn.text: Mr. Rosenthal.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: If it please the Court.
With reference to Mr. Justice Frankfurter's point, Mr. Justice Frankfurter's --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: A question, it wasn't a point.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: -- question on page 235 of the record, there is a --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What page, Mr. --

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: There are the four which the Darlington used in connection with their transient rentals which has on it, "Have you left your key, and rent, security deposits, telephone, furniture rental."
And I suggest that this at least is one indication that this was not a merely ad hoc occasional relationship.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But that doesn't -- that doesn't tell us -- that doesn't give you the quantitative light.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: No, but if the Court pleases, these people, right from the very outset started to rent -- furnish apartments and rent furnished apartments.
They didn't wait to -- and to see whether on a furnished basis, they could attract veterans.
They went right into the furnishing business, they charged, I think the record indicates, $15 to $20 per month more.
So instead of this being $77.50 apartments, they were $92 or $97 apartments.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How long has the practice you complain of been going on (Inaudible)?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: The practice (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Inaudible) I think it is still going on.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: This building was built in -- finished in July of 1951.

They started to furnish in October 1951, they started to rent to transients in February 1 and the FHA didn't know it because when they filed their occupancy report, they disclosed the fact that they were even renting to -- even renting furnished apartments.
Now, insofar as --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: I thought the record showed that the Darlington people had gone to the FHA, had disclosed they were renting the -- wanted to rent these things on a -- on a basis, and asked for their approval of a rent schedule.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: Absolutely not.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Isn't -- am I wrong about that?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: No, the record in -- the record does not indicate that, what the record indicates is that the FHA sometime around to December of 1952 discovers they are renting furnished.
They didn't -- FHA didn't know transient, but they knew that they had furniture in some of these apartments.
So the FHA then says to the Darlington, "You can't do this unless, one, that you get a furniture rental schedule approved, and second, you agree not to rent to transients.

Now, the record doesn't express -- the -- the printed record at any rate does not expressly indicate when the practice of renting to transients was discovered by the FHA, but it's at least an implication from this later correspondence, it wasn't until very late in the game, but they never came and asked for permission.
They were doing this and they were concealing the fact and --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But is there nothing in the record which fairs on the determination of this fact?

That was my question to you in the light of what this -- the Long said, namely that rentals to transients was not a device to make extra money, although they could have rented for -- beyond 30 months, but that was a necessity as a matter of experience.
Some of these apartments would have stood empty and this was a way of utilizing the excess available apartment.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: The Court --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's what Mr. Long said if I understood it.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: If the Court -- if the Court pleases, we -- we don't think that the record indicates one way or the other on that.
We would suggest this that before experience could tell them anything in this instance, right -- beginning with February, they -- they furnished 60 of their units.
Secondly, we would submit that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, how do you know that -- how long -- when -- how soon after apartments were available, did they rent it to the -- the transients?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: They rented to transients.
Well, it was the period from the very end of July to the following February.
Now, on that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: July to February.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But on the other side, I know little about these things, but very often before an apartment house is under way, inquiries are made about future rentals.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: That's -- that's -- that may well be true.
But of course in the interim here, they had taken out 60 apartments without the FHA's knowledge from the -- from the range of unfurnished apartments.
Secondly, and this is we think is the very important point.
And this again, and you view it in terms of the purpose for which this -- this program was established.
These people hit upon the device of furnished apartments and then transients is the way out of their difficulty.
They made no endeavor here to try to and reduce their rents.
The record indicates they were in a poor location.
This isn't the FHA's fault, it was their fault, they insisted upon it.
Before it -- but first, this is being a error of judgment on their part, instead of trying to encourage veterans to come in.
That's the purpose of the program.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Let me --

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: They go out immediately and follow this -- this entirely different task.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Let me ask you a question, Mr. Rosenthal.
So far as I am concerned, if this was an isolated case, this just as Darlington Company --

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: I have some information on that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- down there -- let me put my question.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: Oh, excuse me.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I wouldn't think this was -- the case was fit to be here.
And therefore, the only problem as far as I am concerned is the construction of a statute or the implied powers of the FHA.
What I want to know is this.

Does the FHA, insofar as you are able to speak for it and you ought to be able to speak for it, contend that if as a matter of honest business judgment, an apartment house is practically not rentable and that there is some excess apartment that the owners or the mortgagor may rent that excess, shown by past business experience or allowable judgment, to transients.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: I think --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: As a matter of policy.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: No, the FHA's position today is that even in the so-called hardship cases to which Your Honor has alluded, the congressional prohibition operates that they may not do it.
This that -- and there was one time they took a -- this is right through before 1954, they thought that in the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Has your apartment houses mortgaged prior to 1954?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: That's right (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: They must leave those vacant and not to make (Inaudible) to which you may put its rent.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: Yes.
Of course, they -- they may --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That is your position.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: They may not resort to the transient rental, the advise, in an effort to -- to fill the house.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: They must --

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: It doesn't --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- leave them vacant.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: Oh, no.
There is other -- again, we come down to the fact that there is no -- nothing in this record on which to base an assumption that the Darlington was faced with that desperate Hobson's choice.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm -- I'm trying to -- I'm trying to enlarge this problem away from the Darlington to a general proposition if that's the law of it.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: As -- as a general proposition, we would say that's right, and we would say again this, that if Congress sets up a program for a particular purpose, the beneficiary of that program cannot, because he's unable to make a success of the program -- to working at the program as it was constituted, go in and into some other completely different field of endeavor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That is not as a matter of explicit congressional language, but the implication from the general policy underlying it, right?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: I think that's correct.

Now, I might just -- if I may I say this, in answer to a question that was asked.I had been advised while I was sitting down that there are between 12 to 15 suits now -- no 10 to 15 suits now pending with respect to this transient rental issue which are of course waiting for this decision to -- decision of the Court.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Does that include all of those who were -- who were permitted prior to the 1954 --

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: No, the --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- Act?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: -- no, the people that were permitted, expressly permitted prior, they have an exception.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Those were in -- had a contract to that --

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: Well, it had asked the FHA for permission.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: The FHA --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: -- under the methods of operation clause granted it, that's right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, excluding those, are all of the others treated the same as this -- this one?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: Well, I would -- I would presume -- presume so.
I will check -- ascertain whether in addition to the 10 to 15 lawsuits pending, if there are other --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: -- instances of this, of the persons in the Darlington position which would, if necessarily to --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.
If you will please.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I ask you what I -- excuse me.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: No, no, no.
Please, go ahead.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- what I asked to Mr. Long.
What from your standpoint is the effect on this company, as to the past and as to the future if the Government wins?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: As to the past, there is no effect at all.
The statute is perfectly clear on that, that the -- the statute does not impose any kind of liabilities with respect to the past, so that the Government --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is the Government is claiming that it can be (Over Overlap) --

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: No, of course not.
We're not claiming that they are liable for the -- they -- their past transient rental collections at all.
Our -- the effect of this would be simply, that in the future, they would be prohibited from renting these units to transients.
They could furnish them, they can rent them on a furnished basis, but not for periods of time less than 30 days.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now, would it be possible for you to the Federal Housing Administration to give us the example of the same thing if there are such, in other parts of the country, where they are.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: Examples of?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Of -- of the rental of these units that were built, the lower rental houses for veterans being used for motels or hotels or transients.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: I think that I'll make an endeavor to get them, Your Honors.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You are really suggesting, this is a device to submerge a purpose of their houses.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That is the --

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: That's precisely what --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's your position.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: That's precisely what --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Therefore, the enquiries that Justice Black made have -- seems to me very important.
But as to that --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What have you got to say as to this comment of Judge Hoffman in his opinion?

The unusual situation created by reason of the FHA's insistence to cease the practice of renting apartments for periods of less than 30 days will admittedly necessitate, will admittedly necessitate the financial downfall of the Darlington with the result in the loss of an initial investment together with the monthly payments of $6000 each beginning January or June 1.

It certainly would not justify the continued existence of Darlington, and bankruptcy would be the ultimate answer, the foreclosure of the mortgage would follow with the Commissioner of the FHA requiring title, as it is a bear assumption, no purchase or sale or there's an amount equal to or in excess of the unpaid balance due on the mortgage.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: I don't -- my recollection is that the Government certainly made no admission.
It -- I think --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: That finding was adopted by the three-judge court afterwards, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: It what is -- that was true on this record or at least appears to be true, is that if the Darlington continues its operation in the manner in which it has been continuing it, leaving off simply the practice of renting the transients that they will be in financial difficulties.

Again, I come back to the -- the point that there's no indication in this record that I can see, that on a lower rental basis or by adopting certain other practices which are within the scope of the -- the statute and the regulations, the Darlington could not make a goal.

But again we would emphasize that if -- even if that so, we say that -- that that isn't a critical consideration here, because these people, I misspoke myself for this purpose, and we think that whether they are -- were unable to make a financial success of the -- the project for the purpose for which it was established.

We think that that's regrettable, but we don't think it is warrant for going into some other completely different line of endeavor and competing with hotels in this case and other transient accommodations which didn't have this type of alien construction, and which Congress clearly, by the 1946 Act, was not intending to setup competition for.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, in that connect, Mr. Rosenthal, what -- what do you have to say to the -- the point Mr. Long raised about this second exception in the 1954 Act where the project is located in an area which the Commissioner determines to be a resort area plus the response of the sponsor of the -- the bill that that would include the entire State of Florida with about 11,000 projects of it.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: The answer is here that -- to that is this, that the Congress as determined by the 1954 Act that it wasn't incumbent upon the FHA, they have been doing before to determine what was hardship cases and what weren't.
The FHA was given no discretion in that regard.

What the Congress decided was that they were going to carve out an exception for the State of Florida, where as a overall basis, it's very difficult during seasons of those years for -- to -- to rent, except on a -- on a transient basis.

Now, that determination, we submit, is hard, works an unconstitutional discrimination against the appellee and we don't think actually the appellee is affected by it and has an -- works then as a challenge.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, but my point is this, when you -- you use this, 1954 Act to establish legislative intent to apply this original act, only to long-term tenancies.
Now, how does this establish any such thing if they eliminate an entire State that has 1100 projects in it.
How does that establish the fact ten years before they intended for the entire nation to be under it?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: Well, of course this intent continued all along, as is seen by the -- the express -- expressed statement of intent in the 1954 Act, which has this -- this provision for resort areas.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And was there any such thing in the prior Act?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: No, no, no.
There could be -- the prior Act did not have any provision for resort areas.
The prior Act wasn't dealing with the -- the transient rental problem directly because the prior Act again was in terms of providing residential housing for veterans.

The Congress then when it was called to their attention that there were these activities beyond the scope of the program as intended, got into the matter of transient rentals, and 513 of course has these particular provisions.

But 513 itself, well it has the -- the resort area exception, again contained the expressed declaration of the congressional intent on the inception of the Housing Act right up to the -- the present time.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What is there in the legislative history to show why they exempted the resort areas?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: Resort areas were exempted, Your Honor, because it was -- they were deemed by Congress to present a special and sui generis situation.
In the resort areas, people in those areas do not -- or -- or very small numbers actually established long-term residence.
In that case, it (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You mean in the entire State of Florida, people don't establish permanent residencies?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: Well, these projects were --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I thought it was one of the fast growing States in the union?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: Yes.
But these projects are presumably are established in the -- are in the resort area.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And you mean that the FHA deliberately established all of these apartment houses in -- in Florida in resort areas where soldiers wouldn't come?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: I don't know -- I don't -- I don't know where the projects were -- were established in Florida.

But Congress in its wisdom chose to -- to setup this -- this resort area exception, but that -- at the same time that they again came down with the reaffirmation of a -- of the legislative intent, we don't think of course --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Reaffirmation was in there, was it?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: Well, if they -- as they viewed it, the Committee Reports viewed it, this was merely a restatement of an intent which they thought had -- was clear enough from the -- the 1946 Act itself when it's preamble.
They weren't thinking of the 1954 Act, Section 513 in terms of a change in the existing law.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You mean that the 1946 Act impliedly without all the resorts?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: No, no, no.
The 1946 Act didn't contain any -- anything to --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you said that this doesn't make a change, in -- in answer to the Chief Justice's question that if this was the purpose of the Housing Act, why should the Housing Act go in for supporting resort -- resort communities instead of communities by which -- which reference common law's housing.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: The initial -- no it made a change in the existing law to that extent, but they didn't view the prohibition, the general prohibition of transient rentals as constituting a departure from existing law.
And we think that the -- the Committee Reports on that indicate that quite clearly, thus, I indicated earlier, the House Committee for its part, it didn't think that there was any --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Did it or didn't it make a change as to resorts?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: It made a change as to resort.
And what Congress was doing in effect was saying that we are going to take over the job which the FHA had been in our -- in the Congress' view was proper in exercising before, under take before.
That of determining what are the -- the hardship cases.
And I said the FHA does not have discretion under the methods of operation, we're going to carve out the two exceptions.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But my question is, why should an inapplicable situation with reference to the purpose of the Housing Act to which resorts, the taking out of the statute or had been in the statute to begin with.Congress wasn't concerned with fly-by-night Florida visitors, was it?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: No.
Congress -- Congress --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And yet it took them out.
And since before that, and you said that, that implied that it was always in there as to every other place.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: No, I don't say that they -- because they took it out from -- took -- included a expressed exception for Florida; as that -- in those that -- it was in as to everybody else before.
I would -- all that I said was that Congress, when they were viewing the problem in 1954, they deemed Section 513 as making no change in its broad scope of an existing law.
They then decided in their wisdom and this is we submit is an appropriate subject of legislative resolution whether we might agree with it or not, then decided to --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But it would -- it would get nonsense to Congress if you can help it.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: But they then decided to carve out the -- the Florida exception and we think there's no question from the enforcement provisions of this Act as well as from subsection (b), that contrary what Mr. Long has suggested, the Act in terms applies to existing projects as well as projects built subsequent to 1954.
Of course, Section 608 itself, there have been no mortgages insured under that section since 1950, the program expired, even though they still are permanent mortgage programs.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Rosenthal, are there any other states that come under the umbrella of this -- of this section?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: Not to my knowledge Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Are there any other great areas that are denominated as -- as resort areas?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: Not to my knowledge.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: It applies only to the State of Florida.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: It is -- that is my understanding of this restriction in its operation to the State of Florida.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And why -- why then didn't they say so in the Act and -- and why did they leave it to this -- to this conversation between the sponsor of the bill and the Senator from Florida as to --

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: That --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- to whether it excluded the whole -- whole State of Florida?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: That, Your Honor, I don't know but I could guess.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But that's the interpretation that the FHA puts out.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: That's -- but that's -- that's right.
And that again, that the statute declared --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Florida -- State of Florida is out --

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: That's the way I --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: because of that --

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: -- that's how I understand that.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- conversation in the -- in the legislative history.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: That is --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- and not by reason of any words that are in the Act.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: That is my understanding, if I'm wrong in this regard, I will --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: -- correct it by statement.
It is my understanding.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: That is how --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That is that your understanding also that it was -- that, that conversation limited it specifically to -- to the State of Florida and did not mean other -- other resort areas where they'd use this language?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: All, but I wouldn't go to that extent.

That all that I -- that I would state at this point is, it's -- it's my understanding that the -- the Federal Housing Administration is -- is applying the resort area exception to the State of Florida and I know of no other things in other States.
And whether --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, will you let us know please if it is applying it to any other States besides Florida and if so, to what States?
And if not, to entire States, to what resort areas?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: I will do that.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: If you please.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: May -- may an Easterner say that Southern California is -- is repeatable in those areas?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: [Laughs] Well, I was again in terms of --[Laughter] -- was again in terms laughing.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: One -- one other question -- one other question.
Does this record contain all the evidence?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If not, where is the other evidence?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Or is it the same to all the evidence undertaken that all in such a plan that (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: This shows the whole evidence that exists with reference to the financial operations and the conditions.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And with reference to whether they could have been rented at a cheaper rate and anything of that kind.
No other evidence except what's in here.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I think -- I think it is planned (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Did the Government put in -- did the FHA put in evidence?

Did the FHA introduce evidence before either Judge Hoffman originally or when it came back to the three-judge court on -- I know the veteran if it's so because they just acted under Judge Hoffman record.
That's how it is.

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: Yes they had a new --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The Government -- did the Government introduce any evidence under that?

turn.speaker: alan_s_rosenthal
turn.label: Mr. Alan S. Rosenthal
turn.text: Yes.
Yes, Your Honor.
They put on the stand two witnesses and a couple of affidavits.
It's in the record.
